title: 114_s1050
content: The Act may be cited as the "Inspiring New STEM Professionals by Investing in Renovation of Education Spaces Act" or the "INSPIRES Act." Congress finds that over the past decade, the growth in STEM jobs has been three times faster than non-STEM jobs. STEM skills are now required in a wide range of occupations, with over 50% of these jobs not needing a bachelor's degree. There may be up to 26 million jobs in the US that require STEM competency. In recent years, STEM workers have lower unemployment rates and higher wages than non-STEM workers. High-performing education facilities are necessary for high-performing students, but many STEM and technical education facilities are outdated and inefficient. SEC. 3. CAREER AND TECHNICAL EDUCATION FACILITIES. Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to include Career and Technical Education Facilities. In this subpart, "career and technical education" is defined as per the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006. "Community college" refers to a junior or community college, or an institution of higher education that awards a significant number of degrees and certificates, excluding baccalaureate degrees. The term 'eligible entity' refers to a local educational agency, community college, or other entity approved by the Secretary. A 'qualified project' involves upgrading facilities to enhance STEM or career education for public school or community college students, including energy efficiency improvements. The eligible entity can use the funds for improving the cost-effectiveness of delivering quality education, enhancing health and safety, upgrading educational technology, retrofitting buildings for career education, and repairing or replacing equipment for educational outcomes. The eligible entity can use the funds for improving educational outcomes, enhancing health and safety, upgrading technology, retrofitting buildings for career education, and repairing or replacing equipment. The funds do not cover new construction or routine maintenance costs. SEC. 5622. CAREER AND TECHNICAL EDUCATION FACILITIES IMPROVEMENT. SEC. 5622 authorizes a program to improve career and technical education facilities through grants, loan guarantees, and interest payments on financial instruments for qualified projects. Eligible entities must submit detailed project descriptions to the Secretary for consideration. The application for the program to improve career and technical education facilities must include a detailed description of the project, educational outcomes, funding preference, project need, maintenance plan, beneficiary schools, and project implementation details. The application for the program to improve career and technical education facilities must include a detailed description of the qualified project's impact on educational outcomes, integration within the curriculum, use for providing STEM or career education services, and compliance with environmental building standards. The application for the program must include a description of the Green Building Initiative standards, fiscal capacity, percentage of low-income students, secondary school graduation rates, and any additional information required by the Secretary. Priority is given to projects that meet these criteria. The Secretary must allocate at least 25 percent of funds for projects benefiting high-need schools or rural community colleges. Funds should supplement, not replace, other federal and state funds. Up to 3 percent of funds may be reserved for administrative costs and technical assistance. The Secretary must allocate a minimum of 25 percent of funds for projects benefiting high-need schools or rural community colleges. Up to 3 percent of funds may be reserved for administrative costs and technical assistance. The Secretary is required to report on the impact of qualified projects on academic achievement every two years. Authorization of appropriations is amended for the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Authorization for Subpart 22 is set at $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and each succeeding year. Conforming amendments are made to the table of contents in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Subpart 22 focuses on career and technical education facilities, including definitions and improvements. Authorization for this subpart is set at $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and each succeeding year, with amendments made to the table of contents in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
